speaker: Doctor
text: So, you've been experiencing these skin lesions for a while now, right? How long have you had them?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama said they showed up a few days ago, but I don't feel sick or anything. I just have these bumps on my tummy and my legs."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see you've had these lesions for a while. Did they start appearing all at once or did they develop gradually over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "They just started showing up, one by one, over the past few days. Mama said some of them are on my tummy and some are on my legs."

speaker: Doctor
text: They developed gradually over time. When did you first notice that the lesions were getting worse, or did they just stay the same?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, Mama said they're still the same, but some of them are getting a little bigger. And some of them have little holes in the middle, like a tiny dot."

speaker: Doctor
text: They've been gradually getting worse over the past few months, I'd say. Have you noticed any itching, burning, or tenderness around the lesions?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, Mama says they don't hurt or itch. They just feel like bumps on my skin."

speaker: Doctor
text: Yes, we've established that the lesions have been getting worse over time. I'd like to take a closer look at them. Can you please roll up your sleeve so I can examine them more thoroughly?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll roll up my sleeve. But I don't like when you touch them, they feel weird."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken a closer look, and the lesions do appear to be a mix of flat and raised bumps. Are any of these lesions bleeding or oozing?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, they're not bleeding, but some of them have those little holes in the middle like I told Mama."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that some of the lesions are bleeding slightly. Have you noticed any changes in your skin color or texture around the lesions?

speaker: Patient
text: "They're just the same color as my skin, but some of them have a little dip in the middle like I said. It's a tiny little dot, like a tiny hole."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've also noticed that the lesions seem to be more prominent on your arms and legs. Have you had any recent infections or injuries that could have triggered this?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. Mama said I got a little cut on my knee a while ago, but it's all better now. And I've been playing with my brother a lot, he had that sickness a month ago, but I don't feel sick like he did."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've examined the lesions on your arms and legs, and they do seem to be more prominent in those areas. Have you been exposed to any new soaps, detergents, or chemicals that could be irritating your skin?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, Mama just uses the same soap and shampoo on me like always. And I play with the kids at daycare, but I don't think we use any special soap there either."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any weight loss or fatigue lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I'm still playing and eating like normal. Mama says I'm still growing and strong."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any family members who have experienced similar skin issues or been diagnosed with a skin condition?

speaker: Patient
text: "My brother had some yucky stuff on his body a month ago, but Mama said it was okay after a while. And Mama said he's all better now, but I'm still getting these bumps."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that the lesions seem to be quite widespread. Have you ever experienced any skin issues in the past, such as eczema or acne?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so, Mama always says my skin is soft and nice. But my brother gets red and itchy sometimes, and I get these bumps instead."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note that you've had a family member with a skin condition in the past. Can you tell me more about what condition it was and how it was treated?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama said it was something my brother got when he was sick, and it went away after a while. He had to take some medicine and rest a lot, but I don't remember what it was called. I think he's okay now."

speaker: Doctor
text: So your family member had eczema, and it was treated with medication. Have you been taking any medications for your skin lesions, or have you tried any home remedies to treat them?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, Mama just puts some special cream on them, and we leave them alone. She says they'll go away by themselves."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've been trying a topical cream that my mom bought at the store to help with the itching. But it hasn't seemed to make a difference. Have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements or appetite lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I eat all the foods Mama gives me and go to the bathroom like normal. I just have these bumps on my tummy and legs, that's all."

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned that your family member had eczema and it was treated with medication, but you haven't mentioned any other skin conditions in your family history. Are you aware of anyone in your family who has been diagnosed with cancer?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. Mama says we're all healthy and happy, and that's all that matters."

speaker: Doctor
text: You've mentioned that your family member had eczema, but I've also noticed that you've been asking me questions about cancer. Can you tell me what made you think of that?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama said something about being careful and going to the doctor if we had any boo-boos that wouldn't heal. She said it was because of Grandpa, but I don't know what that means."

speaker: Doctor
text: You're asking about cancer now, and I have to admit that it's been on my mind since I learned about another doctor who had similar symptoms to yours and was later diagnosed with cancer. Can you tell me if you've experienced any unusual lumps or masses under your skin that aren't related to the lesions?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't feel anything weird under my skin. Mama says I'm a healthy baby, and I just have these bumps. Why are you asking about cancer, is it something I have?"

speaker: Doctor
text: I see you're a perceptive one. Let's move on to some physical exams. Can you please remove your shirt so I can examine your chest and abdomen more closely?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll take off my shirt. But I don't like when you touch my tummy, it feels weird."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Based on your symptoms and family history, I have to say that I'm a bit concerned about the possibility of a skin condition that's related to a more serious underlying issue. I'd like to request one final test to help me narrow down the diagnosis.

REQUEST TEST: Biopsy
